body:
Could the summary be more informative, maybe `{first line} ... [{n} lines]`?

E.g. `import sys ... [10 lines]` tells me something about what's going on. Users would probably start putting a brief summary of the cell in a first-line comment, as well (`# imports`, `# helper functions`) etc. Or if the cell has a function or class definition, the `def` or `class` line is informative.

The input prompt is being reserved for a number of other things:
- We would like to use it as a handle area for sort-by-dragging cells.  Or...
- We would like to use it as a clickable area for bringing up a context menu for each cell.  If we go this direction, the collapse input functionality could be in that menu.

There is another issue related to CodeMirror.  I am been having a really difficult time with hiding and showing the code mirror editor area.  Basically any changes which affect how it is displayed are causing glitches that make the notebook unusable.  With Markdown cells, this has become an "almost show stopper".  I am trying to get a handle on what is going on, but it is really difficult to track down - the bugs are subtle, transient and inconsistent.  We currently have a number of very fragile hacks put into place as workarounds.  But, with this background I am extremely hesitant to do anything that would hide/show/collapse the CodeCells.

I think we absolutely need this functionality, but I think we need to wait until these things are sorted out.

In terms of UI, what about a [-] collapse button that appears below the input prompt when you go to a second line? Then clicking on the collapsed cell itself would expand it and put the cursor inside it.
I'll try to have a base, but if @ellisonbg think we should wait for CodeMirror to be more cleanly integrated maybe there will be a better solution later.

I am trying to make some headway on fixing the CodeMirror bugs right now.  But I do think we need a unified approach for per cell actions - hide input is no more special than hide output, move up, move down, run, etc.  If we start trying to put different UI elements for each of those actions on cells, we will quickly have a cluttered UI.

Well, some actions are going to be more commonly used than others, and putting them all in menus makes them hard to discover and inconvenient to use. With cell collapsing in particular, there's a common paradigm in editors and IDEs for code folding that I think it makes sense to adapt.

Rebased on master, implement @takluyver idea, and make sure code mirror get focus when expanding.
Action is still trigger by click on prompt until you know what kind of UI you want.

I would like to expose my opinion About the UI, I'm usually a fan  of clean minimalistic UI, but I think some action deserved to be (also) outside of menu.

I think that cell/input collapsing is different from cell moving in the way that when you move a cell, you keep it in focus, and you can want to  move one cell 3 times up. In the other hand ,you will never 'copy' 5 different cells in a row. 
The `move up` in a way, deserve to be easily accessible in a repetitive way.

That the reason why I **do** find the `move cell up` in a menu _really annoying_ because it's complicated to click it twice or more, and `C-m k` is not that easy to type several time in a row. Same would apply to a menu or any attached to the cell ui-item that would move at every click and that I can't just click several time (in the case  move up/down).

For cell collapsing, menu are not convenient neither, because to collapse a cell you have to 
- select a cell
- go to the menu to to collapse it/ type the shortcut
- selet the next cell
- find the menu..etc

Which get tedious if you want to collapse multiple cells... almost the same as moving up/down but with the fact that you, even more, apply it on different object each time.

For that mater, for **some** action, the left paned was **really** convenient because it brought any action I would like to repeat N times at (2+N) click from me , versus the (2N) clicks of the menubar or (2N) keypress of the keyboard.

One might argue that people just have to use keyboard shortcut to be fast, but I think IPython target a wide enough range of user to have accessible enough interface. 

In my own experience, I also find that users tend to not see functionality when they are hidden in menu...but that's a different story.

This is my opinion as an "occasional" User of IPython, and that's why with my small experience, I think some things might be enhanced. As I'm not really confortable with english, so I would like to precise that this is 100% friendly and I'm far for critiscising anybody's works, I do find that @ellisonbg is doing an extraordinary work and I'm just trying to give the more precise feedback of how I feel things are/should be/should not be to help improve IPython.

> I would like to expose my opinion About the UI, I'm usually a fan  of clean minimalistic UI, but I think some action deserved to be (also) outside of menu.

Yes, I agree.

> I think that cell/input collapsing is different from cell moving in the way that when you move a cell, you keep it in focus, and you can want to  move one cell 3 times up. In the other hand ,you will never 'copy' 5 different cells in a row.
> The `move up` in a way, deserve to be easily accessible in a repetitive way.
> 
> That the reason why I **do** find the `move cell up` in a menu _really annoying_ because it's complicated to click it twice or more, and `C-m k` is not that easy to type several time in a row. Same would apply to a menu or any attached to the cell ui-item that would move at every click and that I can't just click several time (in the case  move up/down).
> 
> For cell collapsing, menu are not convenient neither, because to collapse a cell you have to
>  \* select a cell
>  \* go to the menu to to collapse it/ type the shortcut
>  \* selet the next cell
>  \* find the menu..etc
> 
> Which get tedious if you want to collapse multiple cells... almost the same as moving up/down but with the fact that you, even more, apply it on different object each time.
> 
> For that mater, for **some** action, the left paned was **really** convenient because it brought any action I would like to repeat N times at (2+N) click from me , versus the (2N) clicks of the menubar or (2N) keypress of the keyboard.

There is no doubt that for some actions the L panel ws better than
then menu.  We absolutely need to have a set of UI elements that
address this issue.  Our plan is to implement a thin button bar below
the menu bar and put common actions there.

> One might argue that people just have to use keyboard shortcut to be fast, but I think IPython target a wide enough range of user to have accessible enough interface.

Yes, many, if not most, users don't use keyboard shortcuts.

> In my own experience, I also find that users tend to not see functionality when they are hidden in menu...but that's a different story.
> 
> This is my opinion as an "occasional" User of IPython, and that's why with my small experience, I think some things might be enhanced. As I'm not really confortable with english, so I would like to precise that this is 100% friendly and I'm far for critiscising anybody's works, I do find that @ellisonbg is doing an extraordinary work and I'm just trying to give the more precise feedback of how I feel things are/should be/should not be to help improve IPython.

Thanks!

> ---
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/ipython/ipython/pull/1300#issuecomment-3631937

## 

Brian E. Granger
Cal Poly State University, San Luis Obispo
bgranger@calpoly.edu and ellisonbg@gmail.com

I'm torn on this one.  On the one hand, many thanks @Carreau for continuing to work on improving the UI, we really appreciate this!  But as @ellisonbg mentioned, the prompt area will probably be necessary to trigger the appearance of some UI element like a local cell-level menu.  It's one of the few areas where it seems possible to activate UI elements without consuming additional vertical space.

Furthermore, we want to carefully consider a few things:
- now that we almost have structural cells (#1331), it becomes possible to consider folding entire sections, not just the internal content of one cell.  We should consider that right now, so we end up with a consistent design throughout.  In particular, how do we distinguish between folding the content of a cell itself (what you have implemented here for code cells) and folding the hierarchy that sits below a cell (to fold entire sections, for example).
- I don't think we should merge folding support until that information can be persisted.  Basically, if I save a notebook with a bunch of cells folded, I'd like to see them folded again when I reopen it later.  Otherwise, if it's an action that has to be enabled every time you open a document, I don't find it too useful.

That means we need to consider where to store that information, which will be per-cell.  I think it should be part of the cell's metadata, but that must play also with the point above about folding both contents and hierarchy, both of which would need to be stored.

So I definitely think this is a worthwhile idea, and it's great to have you working on it! But we need to think this one through very carefully, so it 'clicks' cleanly with the rest...

Non, problem, I just wanted it for some time, and it was just a quick draft, I didn't planed on keeping the action on the input prompt. One idea would be to show the action below the prompt only when the cell is more than 2 or 3 lines, because is does not make sens to collapse a one line cell. 
A bout the persistance of the information, I agree.
I doesn't have much time to work right now, and for know it's hard to keep on with all the change happening (I'm desesperatly hop to be able to test the vim keymap of the notebook), so do I close the PR, or leave it open as a reminder of what have still to be done ?

My suggestion would be to close this PR, but open an issue about code folding that references it. That way we can more easily find it later when we return to the problem.

But I prefer not to keep PRs lingering for a long time.  Since ultimately this code is unlikely to be merged in this form exactly, as a PR it's not very useful in the long run.  But as reference for ideas/implementation in the context of an issue on this topic, it's perfect.
